text:
He searched for his kidnapped son for nearly 24 years. He drove across more than 300,000 miles of China by motorbike. He displayed photos of his two-year-old boy.

This week, Guo Gangtang's search finally ended. https://t.co/LbmYdIL7a6

"I love her more now than I did to begin with — which is saying a lot, because I loved her a lot," Jimmy Carter said of his wife, Rosalynn, as the former first couple approaches their 75th wedding anniversary. https://t.co/zuYueiYrsl

Norway’s women's beach handball players were each fined 150 euros for wearing shorts rather than bikini bottoms. Men are allowed to wear shorts. A spokeswoman for the International Handball Federation said she did not know the reason for the rules. https://t.co/DUuaoGKhIi
Zaila Avant-garde became the first Black American student to win the Scripps National Spelling Bee. The winning word was “murraya.” https://t.co/rxwsPlfzeG https://t.co/YQPAuvg9TP

A digital calico cat the size of a yacht is melting hearts in Tokyo. Visitors are only treated to a few brief appearances per hour and it behaves like an actual cat — in the sense that it does whatever it pleases. https://t.co/qx4Ms4ujLE https://t.co/dEoRXGS84l

Rep. Adam Kinzinger is one of the few Republicans speaking out against the big lie that the presidential election was stolen.

“If you’re scared to tell the truth to people, I understand, but you need to find a different line of work,” he tells @NYTMag.
https://t.co/URh0UeP2M3

Shouting “Freedom” and other anti-government slogans, hundreds of Cubans took to the streets in cities around the country on Sunday to protest food and medicine shortages, in a remarkable eruption of discontent not seen in nearly 30 years. https://t.co/BbqQPLrNiE

Italy announced plans to bar large cruise ships from entering Venice and declared the city’s lagoon a national monument.

The ban, demanded for decades by residents and environmentalists, takes effect on Aug. 1. https://t.co/CRXeSCg6Eg

"I love her more now than I did to begin with — which is saying a lot, because I loved her a lot," Jimmy Carter said of his wife, Rosalynn, as the former first couple approaches their 75th wedding anniversary. https://t.co/ED61J1NtsK

"Senator Paul," Dr. Anthony Fauci said during a Senate hearing on Tuesday, "you do not know what you are talking about, quite frankly, and I want to say that officially." 

Read more: https://t.co/I8rOm7xuim https://t.co/ifhWUnm5v6

"Senator Paul," Dr. Anthony Fauci said during a Senate hearing on Tuesday, "you do not know what you are talking about, quite frankly, and I want to say that officially." 

Read more: https://t.co/jI60pxWS6o https://t.co/PJydwlzJg5
Nikole Hannah-Jones, the leader of The Times’s 1619 Project, was granted tenure by the University of North Carolina after a weekslong dispute. https://t.co/BTJHUjHbsd

Indiana University can require students to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, a federal judge affirmed on Monday. It appeared to be the first ruling upholding a Covid vaccine mandate by a university. https://t.co/daZdNmbm3E
Lionel Messi finally won a major title with his national team after years of agonizing failures as Argentina beat Brazil to win the Copa América. https://t.co/fZzjgjNjis
Breaking News: The FDA is planning to warn that the Johnson & Johnson coronavirus vaccine can increase the risk of a rare nerve condition known as Guillain-Barré syndrome. https://t.co/HP3GFKFzsG

The FBI said some of the 4,500 tips it received about Justice Brett Kavanaugh during its investigation into sexual misconduct allegations against him were given to the Trump White House, leading some Democrats to call the process a sham. https://t.co/vp4eq75JLC
A giant rotating Earth made of drones appeared above Olympic Stadium at the #Tokyo2020 opening ceremony as John Lennon’s “Imagine” played. https://t.co/vzWDufG2nQ https://t.co/iIQjEr6Vpa

There's a huge digital cat on a billboard in Tokyo. 🏙🐱🏙

It says “nyannichiwa” to passers-by, a blend of “konnichiwa,” or hello, and “nyan,” Japanese for “meow.” https://t.co/YzDyaLTIfw

Biz Markie, the innovative rapper, DJ and producer whose “Just a Friend” became an unlikely hit, died at 57.
https://t.co/j0we0Jf3SJ

The Utah Division of Wildlife Resources said that last week it used planes to stock fish in about 200 lakes that are inaccessible by vehicle. The division said it has aerial-stocked fish since the 1950s and that they have a high survival rate. https://t.co/HP2BEDHezI https://t.co/eV5qC7CRpk

“M-U-R-R-A-Y-A.”

Watch the moment Zaila Avant-garde, a 14-year-old from Louisiana, won the Scripps National Spelling Bee, becoming the first Black American to take the top spot in almost a century of contests. 🐝
https://t.co/AZLqyIsnbu https://t.co/jTHuGf17rv

Even after 24 years of searching, Guo Gangtang never gave up hope that he would find his kidnapped son.

This week, they were reunited. https://t.co/vHWpaN6s1a https://t.co/9gk1vcSSuE

Mat George, co-host of "She Rates Dogs," a popular podcast known for his humorous takes on dating, pop culture and his identity as a gay man, was struck and killed by a car as he crossed the street on Saturday in what the authorities called a hit-and-run. https://t.co/llutCTePJo

Nigeria upset a Team U.S.A. team stacked with N.B.A. stars, becoming the first African team to beat the U.S. men’s national team.
https://t.co/PL5QpqRLwk

Mj Rodriguez became the first transgender person to land an #Emmys nomination in a lead acting category. 

She was nominated for best actress in a drama for the final season of “Pose.” https://t.co/EqrnrXzcfe https://t.co/KvlbBitbok

Olivia Rodrigo, the 18-year-old pop star with the No. 1 album in the country, visited the White House to encourage the young and unvaccinated to get their shots. The singer has millions of followers on social media who hang on her every word. https://t.co/DuBcsF2nqy
Henry Parham, a solider in the only all-Black combat unit to land on the beaches of Normandy on D-Day, has died. He was 99. https://t.co/r2e4mmzfu2

Breaking News: A federal judge in Texas ruled DACA unlawful, saying that Barack Obama exceeded his authority when he created the program by executive order. The program has shielded hundreds of thousands of undocumented young adults from deportation. https://t.co/fF4TqW8kB1

"The hot, shirtless Tongan flagbearer from Rio is BACK!"

Pita Taufatofua became an overnight sensation five years ago when he marched shirtless and in a traditional Tongan outfit at the opening ceremonies in 2016 and 2018. He is back for #Tokyo2020. https://t.co/lSzzr8Lsf4 https://t.co/bT2HlMoKhO

Norwegian Cruise Line sued Florida on Tuesday over a state law that would fine businesses up to $5,000 if they force customers to provide proof of vaccination. The company accused the state of preventing it from “safely and soundly” resuming trips. https://t.co/Ua7e5bYS89
Breaking News: Rachel Nichols will not work as a sideline reporter for the NBA finals, ESPN said. She will be replaced by Malika Andrews. https://t.co/eGjcuMtFaN
Breaking News: A grand jury is said to have indicted the Trump Organization and one of its top executives, Allen Weisselberg, in connection with a tax investigation. https://t.co/IQv3vcBD97

Rep. James Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina and the highest-ranking Black member of Congress, took a rare step into a party primary to endorse the leading opponent of Nina Turner, who is an outspoken ally of Senator Bernie Sanders. https://t.co/aUIwHdUxIp

The Biden administration is expected to announce that it will restore protections to Tongass National Forest in Alaska, one of the world’s largest intact temperate rain forests. Former President Donald Trump had previously stripped away the protections. https://t.co/FP1PgUZ2QJ

Bryce Dershem was less than a minute into his valedictorian speech about his queer identity when the principal appeared to turn off his microphone and take away his prepared remarks. So he recited the speech from memory. https://t.co/oWnlbuoa0R https://t.co/hwb49ZoThe

He was alone in Alaska, sleep-deprived and nearly out of ammunition. Well, he wasn't really alone. A bear was following him.

But then help arrived. https://t.co/gJzNwIAaUU

Today, flying the American flag from the back of a pickup truck or over a lawn is increasingly seen as a clue, albeit an imperfect one, to a person’s political affiliation in a deeply divided nation. https://t.co/TODmHEmPsO

In Opinion

Dolly Parton tried to get people vaccinated, but in Tennessee "the bonehead politicians running this state managed to overcome even the good will generated by its favorite daughter," Margaret Renkl writes in a guest essay.
https://t.co/9Mjjv6GUsA

A California woman who falsely accused a Black teenager of stealing her phone and then attacked him at a New York City hotel was charged with a hate crime. A video of her confronting Keyon Harrold Jr., then 14, in December gained widespread attention. https://t.co/rgBQ22GnQx

Maria Taylor, a popular ESPN studio host, has left the company, ESPN announced Wednesday.

The departure had been expected since early this month, when The New York Times reported on disparaging comments made about Taylor by her colleague, Rachel Nichols. https://t.co/7NtN7x1OWB

Jill Biden, the first lady, will appear on the cover of the August issue of Vogue, continuing a tradition that Anna Wintour, the magazine’s editor, had paused during the Trump presidency. https://t.co/7x5YdqshBk

Breaking News: Thousands of Cubans on Sunday protested power outages, food shortages and a lack of medicine — an astonishing act of defiance against a government known for quashing dissent. President Biden called the protests a "clarion call for freedom." https://t.co/GpjTBga9y7 https://t.co/DUAE6WeFuS

Breaking News: An artificial intelligence lab called DeepMind predicted the shapes of hundreds of thousands of proteins in hours — a task that takes scientists years. The technology could greatly accelerate medical and scientific research.
https://t.co/L9ZBTamYh5

For some, Jan. 6 was just a rally for their president. For others, it was more.

The New York Times spent months collecting and analyzing footage from the Capitol riot. We scoured radio communications. We interviewed witnesses. Here’s what we found. https://t.co/0EQ2JilQgN

Ben & Jerry’s will stop selling its ice cream in Israeli-occupied territories, the company announced Monday, plunging itself into one of the world's most fraught issues and angering many prominent Israelis. https://t.co/W5yECRXEsr
YouTube removed videos from President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil for spreading misinformation about the coronavirus. https://t.co/GycCrDqhpy
Older men and women who walked for six months showed improvements in white matter and memory, while those who danced or did stretching exercises did not. https://t.co/1651BA6gvn
Coca-Cola changed the flavor of its soda in 1985 and enraged a nation. Now, the company is doing it again, risking another outcry. https://t.co/tRoVsUG2hH

In a case that has riveted Iran, a couple confessed to murdering and dismembering their son, years after killing a daughter and son-in-law.

“I have no guilty conscience,” the 81-year-old husband said. “I killed people who were very morally corrupt.” https://t.co/f9MvXMn7iQ

Alarms blared across an intensive care unit in Delhi, India. Over two dozen Covid patients on ventilators couldn’t breathe. Staff members did all they could, but it wasn’t enough — the hospital had run out of oxygen. Within seven hours, 21 people died. https://t.co/8FHLjqF5oA

Facing 72-hour work weeks and rising housing prices, many young people in China fear they will be the first generation not to do better than their parents. They are now defying the country’s long-held prosperity narrative by refusing to participate in it. https://t.co/YidkEuci1A

Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene was suspended from Twitter for 12 hours, the company said on Monday, after she posted messages that violated its policy against sharing misleading information about the coronavirus. https://t.co/nG5Kn5JXJh

Olivia Rodrigo, the 18-year-old pop star with the No. 1 album in the country, visited the White House on Wednesday and joined the Biden administration’s efforts to use the young and influential to reach the young and unvaccinated. https://t.co/Fbcshrz6Vd https://t.co/ReI5DuC8dD

Children are taught to identify traitors. Neighbors are urged to report one another. Officials are pressed to pledge their loyalty. 

One year after it imposed a national security law, China has remade Hong Kong. This is how the city’s freedom was taken. https://t.co/zyIRIFvNad

President Emmanuel Macron of France announced new vaccination requirements, including mandatory inoculation for health care workers and proof of immunization or a recent negative test to enter restaurants and cultural venues. https://t.co/MNNzf9qvfl

Ida B. Wells, an investigative reporter who exposed the systematic lynching of black men in the South, was born 159 years ago today. She was considered the most famous Black woman in the U.S.

Her obituary is part of our Overlooked series.
https://t.co/WD6Vy6WFAV

Almost an entire family from Texas — a father, mother, and three of their kids — were charged on Tuesday with breaching the Capitol on Jan. 6. “We were in capital!!…I do mean IN the building!!” Dawn Munn wrote in a Facebook message obtained by the FBI. https://t.co/zt3quio2TN

Yale School of Drama, one of the most prestigious programs in the U.S., plans to stop charging tuition after receiving a $150 million gift from the billionaire David Geffen.

It is the largest gift in American theater history, Yale said. https://t.co/YeFlrmLJs8

The discovery of unmarked graves at former schools for Indigenous children in Canada has revived conversations about the profound damage inflicted on generations of Indigenous families.

These photos show the relentless effort to erode their culture
https://t.co/q0Vch4sp2G https://t.co/TaWAKlH41R

Naomi Osaka followed in the footsteps of Muhammad Ali, Paavo Nurmi, Rafer Johnson, Midori Ito, Yuna Kim and Wayne Gretzky and lit the Olympic cauldron to cap Friday's opening ceremony.
https://t.co/QMsUB3Ljr6 https://t.co/o24TVNx7Wr
The American sprinter Sha’Carri Richardson, who was set to compete at the Tokyo Olympics this month, could miss the Games after testing positive for marijuana. https://t.co/X5wsYcQiUt
Breaking News: Allen Weisselberg, a top executive at the Trump Organization, surrendered to the Manhattan district attorney’s office to face charges, officials said. https://t.co/7MmwhW22LE

Donald Trump twice sought to talk on the phone with the Republican leader of Arizona’s largest county last winter as the Trump campaign tried to reverse the state’s election results, according to the official and records obtained by The Arizona Republic. https://t.co/epn7updDQZ

Breaking News: The FBI failed to respond quickly to accusations of sexual abuse against the former USA Gymnastics doctor Larry Nassar, allowing him to abuse dozens of more victims, a federal report said. https://t.co/7851jvlrX1
Breaking News: Italy rallied to beat England and win #Euro2020, dashing English hopes for their first major title since the 1966 World Cup. https://t.co/dPspUeRzpn

Jessica Springsteen, the daughter of Bruce Springsteen and Patti Scialfa, is ranked 27th in the world in show jumping and has a good chance to win a medal at the Tokyo Olympics. https://t.co/0JtQAmnq9v

Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York plans to propose legislation on Wednesday to decriminalize marijuana at the federal level.

The draft bill would remove marijuana from the Controlled Substances Act and begin regulating and taxing it. https://t.co/AEyzKLsoqJ

Breaking News: An Iranian-American journalist living in Brooklyn was the target of an international kidnapping plot orchestrated by an Iranian intelligence network, federal prosecutors said. https://t.co/Dnp6s96iMV

Prince William and Prince Harry reunited briefly to unveil a statue of their mother, Princess Diana, on what would have been her 60th birthday.

“Every day, we wish she were still with us,” the brothers said in a rare joint statement. https://t.co/26IGxZSqOD https://t.co/cALMO8pUxr

Protests over the imprisonment of the former South African president Jacob Zuma have escalated into looting and other destructive lawlessness. Some analysts and activists said the uprising was born of deeper issues of poverty and lack of opportunity. https://t.co/p0r51WJ7Tl https://t.co/YBGrImtSOo
One of the few issues on which Democrats and Republicans seem to agree: “Free Britney.” https://t.co/w8ONMnros0
Pedro Castillo, a political outsider, was elected president of Peru on Monday, becoming the country’s first left-wing leader in more than a generation. https://t.co/axZYMaX365

Breaking News: Parts of the Amazon are now emitting more carbon dioxide than they absorb, reducing the forest’s ability to be a buffer for climate change, a new study found. Deforestation and global warming have contributed to the change. https://t.co/bzj2E1Y5CW
Dilip Kumar, one of India’s earliest Method actors who ruled Hindi cinema in the 1950s and 1960s, died at 98. https://t.co/VPSbTwEUUf
Cleansing your timeline with David Harbour and his four-month-old puppy. https://t.co/SjwaU7IzM2 https://t.co/e7QK7xrXor

A homeopathic doctor in California is the first person to face federal charges for selling fake Covid vaccination cards, the authorities said. She faces up to 20 years in prison and hundreds of thousands of dollars in fines. https://t.co/dqPoPycIdj
The Johnson & Johnson coronavirus vaccine is effective against the highly contagious Delta variant, even eight months after inoculation, the company reported on Thursday. https://t.co/yrSE7BV0Jx

The Biden administration is expected to take its first steps Thursday toward finalizing a ban on surprise medical bills. Some experts see the policy as the most important consumer protection in health care to come out of Washington in more than a decade. https://t.co/6iE6EF28UU

Erin Gilmer, a lawyer and disability rights activist who fought for medical privacy, lower drug prices and a more compassionate health care system as she confronted a cascade of illnesses that left her unable to work or get out of bed, has died at 38. https://t.co/qUaDXyGVK5

A California woman who falsely accused a Black teenager of stealing her phone and then attacked him at a New York City hotel was charged with a hate crime. A video of her confronting Keyon Harrold Jr., then 14, in December gained widespread attention. https://t.co/na5Avr4VO6

Mary Wallace Funk, a trailblazing 82-year-old pilot who was prevented from becoming an astronaut in the 1960s because she was a woman, will join Jeff Bezos on his rocket ship company’s first human flight into space, the company announced on Thursday. https://t.co/lSBv11IuND

Last month was the hottest June on record in North America. 1,200 daytime records were broken in the final week.

But there was an even greater number of daily records set by a different — and maybe more dangerous — measure: overnight temperatures. https://t.co/KJhv5KeZ7L

The Spanish artistic swimmer Ona Carbonell is expressing her “disappointment and disillusionment” that it is not practical to bring her son to Japan for the Tokyo Olympics while she is breastfeeding him.
https://t.co/6iGsbRm6WW
What the world needs now are trees, more trees 🌳 https://t.co/fLkRbXHP9g
Lionel Messi finally ticked the last empty box in his soccer career on Saturday night, leading Argentina past Brazil, 1-0, in the final of the Copa América. https://t.co/eJPffY3C9N

He searched for his kidnapped son for nearly 24 years. He drove across more than 300,000 miles of China by motorbike. He displayed photos of his two-year-old boy.

This week, Guo Gangtang's search finally ended. https://t.co/mfABkTWpYB

Breaking News: A group of Texas Democrats fled the state in an effort to block a GOP-backed voting law. More than 50 Democrats signed on, an official involved said, enough to prevent Republicans from attaining the quorum needed to conduct business. https://t.co/iPjADFdXK7

Eve Adams, a gay writer and Polish Jew, published “Lesbian Love,” one of the earliest examples of America lesbian literature, in 1925.

She was deported to Poland from the U.S. in 1927 and later died at Auschwitz.

This is her story.
https://t.co/i2XeZ9dLYw

A California couple who mowed down 36 protected Joshua trees to clear their land for a new house have been fined $18,000, a punishment the authorities hope will discourage others from uprooting the iconic desert plants. https://t.co/m9nSBKnXNk
Thanks to a NASA robot that landed on Mars in 2018, scientists now have a map of the red planet’s inner workings down to its core, the first ever made of another planet. https://t.co/6nmk58ZJSD

Executives at Activision Blizzard sexually harassed women, a California state agency said in a lawsuit, and male employees openly joked about rape and drank alcohol while engaging in “inappropriate behavior” toward women at their cubicles. https://t.co/WgXWYQNaMB
Older men and women who walked for six months showed improvements in white matter and memory, while those who danced or did stretching exercises did not. https://t.co/FazgDj1gwa

Malta will ban visitors over the age of 12 unless they’re fully vaccinated against the coronavirus. It is the first EU country to impose such restrictions as the island sees an increase in cases amid the Delta variant’s spread. https://t.co/vkSBLrMf1W

Our investigation revealed at least eight locations where rioters breached the Capitol, more than previously identified.

In some, police battled rioters before being forcibly overwhelmed. In others, officers stepped aside. https://t.co/eF9TC4KQYJ
People who test positive for the coronavirus should distance themselves from not only humans, but pet cats and dogs as well. “You cannot cuddle them,” one scientist said. https://t.co/cvaQie7dBr
How unusual is the heat that’s been smothering the Pacific Northwest? Off the charts. https://t.co/R0atewMMis https://t.co/W0xBLM1WRT

A Ugandan weight lifter who went missing in Japan last week was found by the police.

Julius Ssekitoleko, who did not make his country’s Olympic squad, left a note saying he wished to work in Japan before he disappeared.
https://t.co/HhD258P2Ly

A Dutch 18-year-old would become the youngest person ever to go to space on Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin rocket launch scheduled for Tuesday. Oliver Daemen takes the spot of another passenger who paid $28 million for the seat but had a scheduling conflict. https://t.co/SPvWMEGdH0

Nearly 900 people in Rome showed up for an overnight vaccination drive targeting “people on the margins of society.” Live music and free espresso and Italian croissants also helped draw in the crowds. https://t.co/4BbdMoMUDS
Allen Weisselberg was removed from his leadership roles at dozens of Trump Organization subsidiaries after being indicted by New York prosecutors. https://t.co/4752IMJJaS

Speaker Nancy Pelosi will bar two Trump allies from the committee investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, she said, because of "statements made and actions taken by these members." https://t.co/pwfYntKC63

The Biden administration is expected to announce that it will restore protections to Tongass National Forest in Alaska, one of the world’s largest intact temperate rain forests. Former President Donald Trump had previously stripped away the protections. https://t.co/G8nCupVS3p

The death toll from the coronavirus pandemic in India so far is likely to exceed three million — nearly 10 times the official figure — making it one of the worst human tragedies in the nation’s history, according to a comprehensive new study.
https://t.co/upckhSJsdV

Next week, for the first time on a broadcast, fans of Major League Baseball can watch a game in which they might not hear a man’s voice.

The Baltimore Orioles versus the Tampa Bay Rays will be called entirely by women. https://t.co/lVfqTu4agN

The Utah Division of Wildlife Resources said that last week it used planes to stock fish in about 200 lakes that are inaccessible by vehicle. The division said it has aerial-stocked fish since the 1950s and that they have a high survival rate. https://t.co/oHWlwAO80K https://t.co/tm1UFSMgM6

Britney Spears won permission Wednesday to hire her own lawyer to represent her as she fights to end the 13-year conservatorship that has governed her life. Last month, Spears called the arrangement abusive and told the court that she wanted it to end. https://t.co/mTEAKsG3Cn

Donald Trump announced plans to sue Facebook, Twitter and Google after the platforms have taken various steps to ban him or block him, and his political operation immediately began fund-raising. “If they can do it to me, they can do it to anyone,” he said. https://t.co/pVJJKdw1Fz

President Emmanuel Macron of France announced new vaccination requirements, including mandatory inoculation for health care workers and proof of immunization or a recent negative test to enter restaurants and cultural venues. https://t.co/p5j03UEypB

A surge in Covid shot appointments in France followed an announcement of new vaccination requirements, including mandatory inoculation for health care workers and proof of immunization or a negative test to enter restaurants and cultural venues. https://t.co/fBDZyS2t4S
Breaking News: Some Florida hospitals have more Covid patients than at any point in the pandemic, as national alarm rises over lagging vaccination rates in parts of the U.S. https://t.co/1mi6OZKbiB
Harvey Weinstein, who was convicted in New York in 2020 and sentenced to 23 years in prison, was transferred to California on Tuesday to face a new round of sex crime charges. https://t.co/0ojPC2vzvE

Breaking News: Texas Democrats are making plans to flee the state on chartered flights to Washington, D.C., a dramatic attempt to block a sweeping Republican bill to restrict voting. It's unclear if enough will join to prevent the bill from moving forward. https://t.co/9bTdtaBwnn
Breaking News: Russia’s most aggressive ransomware group, blamed for multiple attacks on the U.S., suddenly went offline. Who made that happen is a mystery. https://t.co/6E7lgjcpn3

Britain’s women’s soccer team became the first athletes to take a knee at the Olympics. Chile's players then joined the demonstration.
https://t.co/g7UYniPUBp

“For nearly 50 years, this just sat in a basement and no one cared,” Questlove said about the Harlem Cultural Festival footage he watched on loop for months to make his new, acclaimed documentary, “Soul of Summer.” https://t.co/EWgKZa89j3
Zaila Avant-garde became the first Black American student to win the Scripps National Spelling Bee. The winning word was “murraya.” https://t.co/oY54ylKbie https://t.co/kcVfv1KDJw

President Biden hosted a ceremony honoring the Tampa Bay Buccaneers’ 2021 Super Bowl win, where the quarterback Tom Brady stole the show with a pair of political jokes that appeared to be jabs at Donald Trump. https://t.co/CQeWvxIqc5 https://t.co/tBmM9Pv6Uh
The number of extremely hot days is rising around the world. See how your hometown has changed since your birth — and how much hotter it may get. https://t.co/vXNuYn12So

Waist-deep water in the subway and flooded highways: Here’s how heavy rains affected New York City on Thursday ahead of Tropical Storm Elsa's arrival.
https://t.co/QcFBTLxu3f https://t.co/s0HUPv0kxl

Several hundred people are gathered near Olympic Stadium in Tokyo to protest holding the Games during the pandemic. The stadium is quiet enough that they are audible during the ceremony. https://t.co/5gtlk6YROh

https://t.co/7TBSguuOFB

Fans quickly repaired a mural of Marcus Rashford, a Black player on England’s soccer team who played in the Euro 2020 final, after it was defaced with racist remarks. https://t.co/BD3CkhFAok https://t.co/N49eye8Nsv

A woman has joined a U.S. Navy special warfare unit for the first time. 

She is the first female graduate of a training pipeline that feeds the Navy SEALs and other elite commando units, the Navy said. https://t.co/WquD0stMbn

As the Delta coronavirus variant rips through conservative areas, Republicans are slowly starting to publicly condemn vaccine hesitancy and misinformation. "The politicization of vaccination is an outrage and frankly moronic,” said Senator Mitt Romney. https://t.co/9NKat6JUaG

The WHO has urged even fully vaccinated people to continue wearing masks and taking other precautions because of concerns about the Delta variant. The guidance is a break with the CDC, which relaxed advice on mask-wearing for vaccinated Americans.
https://t.co/ToBpcjuPMi

Zaila Avant-garde, 14, had already set three Guinness world records (dribbling, bouncing and juggling basketballs) by the time she spelled “murraya” on Thursday to clinch the Scripps National Spelling Bee title and become the first Black American winner. https://t.co/fuS58pKOxM https://t.co/aznBTI6fs8

Indonesia reported more than 54,500 coronavirus cases on Wednesday. “Based on the last three days' data, I can say clearly that Indonesia has become the new epicenter in the world,” said an epidemiologist. https://t.co/FPMslPJ1Pa

The recent heatwave in the Western U.S. and Canada killed hundreds of millions of marine animals, scientists say. Dead mussels and clams coated rocks in the Pacific Northwest, shells gaping open as if they’d been boiled. Sea stars baked to death. https://t.co/bugFNV81ji

A federal jury in Wisconsin found that Walmart had violated the Americans with Disabilities Act and awarded an ex-employee with Down syndrome more than $125 million in damages. https://t.co/qve0zcKIiB

Residents of Mekelle, the capital of Ethiopia’s Tigray region, celebrated in the streets after rebel fighters retook the city from government forces and their allies. It was a dramatic turn in the eight-month civil war. https://t.co/XbcjFCdQQ0 https://t.co/cJMfDPXuFk

“Folks are supposed to have common sense, but it’s time to start blaming the unvaccinated folks, not the regular folks,” Gov. Kay Ivey of Alabama said during a news conference on Thursday. “It’s the unvaccinated folks that are letting us down.” https://t.co/CJ5mOhIQXN
